ygData.subject: Multiagent HyperNEAT Revisited
ygData.msgSnippet: Our 2008 GECCO paper by David D Ambrosio and myself introduced the idea that a single HyperNEAT CPPN can encode a set of neural networks (instead of just one)

Subject: Multiagent HyperNEAT Revisited
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=3ATMliRBfP56l9iaXkGWSwkmtJqOJAzsN6euG-0AFR9sGS4VYqBv

Our 2008 GECCO paper by David D'Ambrosio and myself introduced the idea tha=
t a single HyperNEAT CPPN can encode a set of neural networks (instead of j=
ust one) that represent a pattern of policies for an entire team.  Since th=
en a few people have asked about the way we laid out the team on the substr=
ate and whether alternatives might be better.

I am happy to announce, with=
 my co-authors David D'Ambrosio, Joel Lehman, and Sebastian Risi, that we h=
ave extensively tested such an alternative z-axis-based encoding and publis=
hed the results to appear in AAMAS 2010, available here:

http://eplex.cs.u=
cf.edu/publications/2010/dambrosio.aamas10.html

Direct Link: http://eplex.=
cs.ucf.edu/papers/dambrosio_aamas10.pdf

We believe this z-based substrate =
layout is superior to the previous one, particularly for scaling the size o=
f the team, and should open up the field of multiagent learning further to =
HyperNEAT.  The paper also includes the first published results on scaling =
the size of the team without further training, which works because HyperNEA=
T can interpolate new policies for ANNs inserted along the z axis of the su=
bstrate.  

Videos that accompany the paper are here: 
http://eplex.cs.ucf.=
edu/mahnaamas2010.html

ken
